review.title: On sets of graded attribute implications with witnessed non-redundancy
review.abstract: We study properties of particular non-redundant sets of if-then rules describing dependencies between graded attributes. We introduce notions of saturation and witnessed non-redundancy of sets of graded attribute implications are show that bases of graded attribute implications given by systems of pseudo-intents correspond to non-redundant sets of graded attribute implications with saturated consequents where the non-redundancy is witnessed by antecedents of the contained graded attribute implications. We introduce an algorithm which transforms any complete set of graded attribute implications parameterized by globalization into a base given by pseudo-intents. Experimental evaluation is provided to compare the method of obtaining bases for general parameterizations by hedges with earlier graph-based approaches.

metadata.title: On sets of graded attribute implications with witnessed non-redundancy

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 5.04 677v 1 [cs.A I] We examine the properties of certain non-redundant sets of if-then rules describing dependencies between tiered attributes. We introduce notions of saturation and observe that the non-redundancy of tiered attribute implications shows that fundamentals of tiered attribute implications given by systems of pseudo-intentions correspond to non-redundant sets of tiered attribute applications with saturated consequences, where the non-undancy of ancestors of the tiered attribute implications contained is observed. We introduce an algorithm that converts any complete set of tiered attribute implications parameterized by globalization into a basis given by pseudo-intentions. Experimental evaluation is provided to compare the method of gaining basics for general parameters with previous hedges.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section, we present the basic concepts of Truth Degree Structures and Graded Attribute Implications. Whenever possible, we use the same notation as in [4] for general residuation structures and [18] for graded attribute implications. We use complete residuated lattices as structures of degrees of truth. In our development, these structures represent a reasonable generalization of the most common structures of degrees defined on the real interval defined by means of left triangular norms. [4, 28] is a complete residuated lattice [4,] is an algebra L = < L, 0, 0, 1 > where < L, 0, 1 > is a complete lattice (i.e. a lattice in which infima and suprema exist for arbitrary subsets of L), < L, 1 > is a commentary monoid (i.e.).

sections.heading: 3 Non-Redundant Bases: Overview and Related Work
sections.text: In this section, we present an overview of the existing results in terms of FAI basics. Existing approaches relate to the description of the data bases of object attributes with graduated attributes formalized as formal L contexts: For non-empty finite sentences, the term "X" (set of objects) and "Y" (set of attributes) is used whenever a formal L context I produces a pair of operators.

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: The first observation we present in this section includes sets of FAIs in a special form. From the model theoretical point of view, we show that for each group of FAIs an equivalent group can be found in which the consequences of all the FAIs contained in the group are actually models. This property is introduced in the following definition. Let's be a set of FAIs. We say that the FAIs in a group of FAIs in a group have saturated consequences if there are saturated consequences for each A-group B. Obviously, it depends on whether a given A-group has a saturated sequence. Applicable Proposition 1 follows that FAIs in a group have saturated sequences. iff for each A-group B have saturated consequences. Therefore, if FAIs in a group have saturated consequences, then all FAIs are in the form of A-group.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Observations and Comments
sections.text: In this section, we present another experimental insight into the problem of the FAIs "bases of calculation with attested non-redundancy, based on the observation of the evidence of Theorem 9 and Korolos 11. Recall that the assertions that the hedge used is globalization and Example 4 show that the procedure for arbitrary hedges in general cannot be extended if the first series of our experiments focuses on these phenomena. We have conducted experiments with randomly generated non-redundant sets of FAIs with saturated consequences, it may happen that those of (27) are not equivalent to other attributes. One question is whether such situations are frequent or rare. The first series of our experiments focuses on these phenomena. metadata.abstractText: We study properties of particular non-redundant sets of if-then rules describing dependencies between graded attributes. We introduce notions of saturation and witnessed non-redundancy of sets of graded attribute implications are show that bases of graded attribute implications given by systems of pseudo-intents correspond to non-redundant sets of graded attribute implications with saturated consequents where the nonredundancy is witnessed by antecedents of the contained graded attribute implications. We introduce an algorithm which transforms any complete set of graded attribute implications parameterized by globalization into a base given by pseudo-intents. Experimental evaluation is provided to compare the method of obtaining bases for general parameterizations by hedges with earlier graph-based approaches.
